member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.Interpolation.Algorithms.ChebyshevSecondKindPolynomialInterpolation
member.summary: Barycentric Polynomial Interpolation where the given sample points are chebyshev nodes of the second kind.
member.remarks: This algorithm neither supports differentiation nor integration.

member.summary: Interpolation method

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Interpolation.IInterpolationMethod.Interpolate(System.Double)
member.summary: Interpolate at point t.
member.returns: Interpolated value x(t).

member.summary: Differentiate at point t.
member.param: Interpolated first derivative at point t.
Interpolated second derivative at point t.
member.returns: Interpolated value x(t).

member.summary: Definite Integrate up to point t.
member.param: Right bound of the integration interval [a,t].
member.returns: Interpolated definite integeral over the interval [a,t].

member.summary: True if the alorithm supports differentiation.

member.summary: True if the alorithm supports integration.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Interpolation.Algorithms.ChebyshevSecondKindPolynomialInterpolation.#ctor
member.summary: Create an interpolation algorithm instance.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Interpolation.Algorithms.ChebyshevSecondKindPolynomialInterpolation.Init(System.Double,System.Double,System.Collections.Generic.IList{System.Double})
member.summary: Initialize the interpolation method with the given samples on chebyshev nodes of the second kind in the interval [a,b].
member.param: Left bound of the sample point interval.
Right bound of the sample point interval.
Values x(t) where t are chebyshev nodes over [a,b], i.e. x[i] = x(0.5*(b+a) + 0.5*(b-a)*cos(Pi*i/n))

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Interpolation.Algorithms.ChebyshevSecondKindPolynomialInterpolation.Interpolate(System.Double)
member.summary: Interpolate at point t.
member.returns: Interpolated value x(t).

member.summary: Differentiate at point t.
member.param: Interpolated first derivative at point t.
Interpolated second derivative at point t.
member.returns: Interpolated value x(t).

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Interpolation.Algorithms.ChebyshevSecondKindPolynomialInterpolation.Integrate(System.Double)
member.summary: Definite Integrate up to point t.
member.param: Right bound of the integration interval [a,t].
member.returns: Interpolated definite integeral over the interval [a,t].

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Interpolation.Algorithms.ChebyshevSecondKindPolynomialInterpolation.GenerateSamplePoints(System.Double,System.Double,System.Int32)
member.summary: Generate a set of chebyshev points of the second kind in the interval [a,b]. These are the expected points t for the values v(t) to be provided in .
member.param: Number of sample nodes to generate.
member.returns: Chebyshev points (second kind) in the interval [a,b], i.e. 0.5*(b+a) + 0.5*(b-a)*cos(Pi*i/n)

member.summary: True if the alorithm supports integration.

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.Distributions.ArbitraryDistribution
member.summary: Non-uniform discrete random distribution.

remarks.p: The class ArbitraryDistribution provides integers deviates for any arbitrary (finite) distribution.
The probability Pr(x) for any integer x is proportional to ArbitraryDistribution.ProbabilityMass(x).
See the chapter three of the book Non-uniform variate Generation from Luc Devroye.

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.CholeskyDecomposition
member.summary: Cholesky Decomposition.
member.remarks: For a symmetric, positive definite matrix A, the Cholesky decomposition is an lower triangular matrix L so that A = L*L'. If the matrix is not symmetric or positive definite, the constructor returns a partial decomposition and sets an internal flag that may be queried by the property.

member.name: F:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.CholeskyDecomposition._l
member.summary: Array for internal storage of decomposition.

member.name: F:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.CholeskyDecomposition._isSymmetricPositiveDefinite
member.summary: Symmetric and positive definite flag.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.CholeskyDecomposition.#ctor(MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Matrix)
member.summary: Cholesky algorithm for symmetric and positive definite matrix.
member.returns: Structure to access L and isspd flag.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.CholeskyDecomposition.GetL
member.summary: Return triangular factor.
member.returns: L

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.CholeskyDecomposition.Solve(MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Vector)
member.summary: Solve A*x = b
member.param: A Vector with a dimension as high as the number of rows of A.
member.returns: x so that L*L'*x = b
member.exception: Matrix is not symmetric positive definite.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.CholeskyDecomposition.Solve(MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Matrix)
member.summary: Solve A*X = B
member.param: A Matrix with as many rows as A and any number of columns.
member.returns: X so that L*L'*X = B
member.exception: Matrix is not symmetric positive definite.

member.name: P:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.CholeskyDecomposition.IsSPD
member.summary: Is the matrix symmetric and positive definite?
member.returns: true if A is symmetric and positive definite.

member.name: P:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.CholeskyDecomposition.TriangularFactor
member.summary: Decomposition Triangular Factor Matrix (L).

member.name: F:MathNet.Numerics.Transformations.TransformationConvention.AsymmetricScaling
member.summary: Only scale by 1/N in the inverse direction; No scaling in forward direction.

member.name: F:MathNet.Numerics.Transformations.TransformationConvention.InverseExponent
member.summary: Inverse integrand exponent (forward: positive sign; inverse: negative sign).

member.name: F:MathNet.Numerics.Transformations.TransformationConvention.NoScaling
member.summary: Don't scale at all (neither on forward nor on inverse transformation).

member.name: F:MathNet.Numerics.Transformations.TransformationConvention.Default
member.summary: Universal; Symmetric scaling and common exponent (used in Maple).

member.name: F:MathNet.Numerics.Transformations.TransformationConvention.Matlab
member.summary: Only scale by 1/N in the inverse direction; No scaling in forward direction (used in Matlab). [= AsymmetricScaling]

member.name: F:MathNet.Numerics.Transformations.TransformationConvention.NumericalRecipes
member.summary: Inverse integrand exponent; No scaling at all (used in all Numerical Recipes based implementations). [= InverseExponent | NoScaling]

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.Polynomial
member.summary: Polynomial represents a finite order polynomial with positive powers and constant real coefficients.
member.remarks: The polynomial coefficients are ordered such that c[0] is the constant term and c[n] is the coefficient of z^n, that is y = c[0]*x^0+c[1]*x^1+c[2]*x^2+...

member.param: The highest power. Example: 2*x^3+x-3 has order 3.

member.param: The coefficients vector. The coefficient index denotes the related power (c[0]*x^0+c[1]*x^1+..)

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.Interpolation.Algorithms.ChebyshevFirstKindPolynomialInterpolation
member.summary: Barycentric Polynomial Interpolation where the given sample points are chebyshev nodes of the first kind.
member.remarks: This algorithm neither supports differentiation nor integration.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Interpolation.Algorithms.ChebyshevFirstKindPolynomialInterpolation.#ctor
member.summary: Create an interpolation algorithm instance.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Interpolation.Algorithms.ChebyshevFirstKindPolynomialInterpolation.Init(System.Double,System.Double,System.Collections.Generic.IList{System.Double})
member.summary: Initialize the interpolation method with the given samples on chebyshev nodes of the first kind in the interval [a,b].
member.param: Left bound of the sample point interval.
Right bound of the sample point interval.
Values x(t) where t are chebyshev nodes over [a,b], i.e. x[i] = x(0.5*(b+a) + 0.5*(b-a)*cos(Pi*(2*i+1)/(2*n)))

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Interpolation.Algorithms.ChebyshevFirstKindPolynomialInterpolation.Interpolate(System.Double)
member.summary: Interpolate at point t.
member.returns: Interpolated value x(t).

member.summary: Differentiate at point t.
member.param: Interpolated first derivative at point t.
Interpolated second derivative at point t.
member.returns: Interpolated value x(t).

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Interpolation.Algorithms.ChebyshevFirstKindPolynomialInterpolation.Integrate(System.Double)
member.summary: Definite Integrate up to point t.
member.param: Right bound of the integration interval [a,t].
member.returns: Interpolated definite integeral over the interval [a,t].

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Interpolation.Algorithms.ChebyshevFirstKindPolynomialInterpolation.GenerateSamplePoints(System.Double,System.Double,System.Int32)
member.summary: Generate a set of chebyshev points of the first kind in the interval [a,b]. These are the expected points t for the values v(t) to be provided in .
member.param: Number of sample nodes to generate.
member.returns: Chebyshev points (first kind) in the interval [a,b], i.e. 0.5*(b+a) + 0.5*(b-a)*cos(Pi*(2*i+1)/(2*n))

member.summary: True if the alorithm supports integration.

member.summary: Apply the danielson lanczos transform.

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.Complex
member.summary: Complex numbers class.

remarks.p: The class Complex provides all elementary operations on complex numbers. All the operators +, -, *, /, ==, != are defined in the canonical way. Additional complex trigonometric functions such as , ... are also provided. Note that the Complex structures has two special constant values and .
In order to avoid possible ambiguities resulting from a Complex(double, double) constructor, the static methods and are provided instead.
Since there is no canonical order among the complex numbers, Complex does not implement IComparable but several lexicographic IComparer implementations are provided, see , and .
For mathematical details about complex numbers, please have a look at the Wikipedia

member.name: P:MathNet.Numerics.Complex.Infinity
member.summary: Represents the infinity value. This field is constant.
member.remarks: The semantic associated to this value is a Complex of infinite real and imaginary part. If you need more formal complex number handling (according to the Riemann Sphere and the extended complex plane C*, or using directed infinity) please check out the alternative MathNet.PreciseNumerics and MathNet.Symbolics packages instead.

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.Collection
member.summary: The class Collection contains several utilities performing some basic collection operations (like union, intersection...).

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Collection.#ctor
member.summary: Preventing the instantiation of the class.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Collection.Concat(System.Collections.ICollection,System.Collections.ICollection)
member.summary: Returns a collection resulting from the concatenation from c1 and c2.
member.remarks: The call is performed in O(1) computational time, the concatenated collection is not built explicitly.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Collection.Inter(System.Collections.ICollection,System.Collections.ICollection)
member.summary: Returns a collection resulting from the mathematical intersection of c1 and c2.

remarks.p: The call is performed in O(c1.Count+c2.Count) and the intersection is built explicitly.
The resulting collection will not contain several identical elements.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Collection.Minus(System.Collections.ICollection,System.Collections.ICollection)
member.summary: Returns a collection resulting from the subtraction of the items of c2 to the collection c1.
member.remarks: The call is performed in O(c1.Count+c2.Count)

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Collection.Product(System.Collections.ICollection,System.Collections.ICollection)
member.summary: Returns the cartesian product of the two collections c1 and c2.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Collection.Union(System.Collections.ICollection,System.Collections.ICollection)
member.summary: Returns a collection resulting from the union of the items of c1 and c2.

remarks.p: The call is performed in O(c1.Count+c2.Count) computational time.
The resulting collection will not contain several identical elements.

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.Collection.ConcatCollection
member.summary: The class ConcatCollection is used to perform the mathematical concatenation between two collections.

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.Collection.InterCollection
member.summary: The class InterCollection is used to perform the mathematical intersection between two collections.

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.Collection.UnionCollection
member.summary: The class UnionCollection is used to perform the mathematical union between two collections.

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.Collection.MinusCollection
member.summary: The collection MinusCollection is used to perform the mathematical subtraction of two collections.

member.name: F:MathNet.Numerics.SiConstants.MagneticPermeability

member.name: F:MathNet.Numerics.SiConstants.ElectricPermittivity

member.name: F:MathNet.Numerics.SiConstants.CharacteristicImpedanceVacuum
member.summary: Characteristic Impedance of Vacuum: Z_0 = mu_0*c_0 [Ohm = m^2 kg s^-3 A^-2] (defined, exact; 2007 CODATA)

member.name: F:MathNet.Numerics.SiConstants.GravitationalConstant

member.name: F:MathNet.Numerics.SiConstants.PlancksConstant
member.summary: Planck's constant: h = 6.62606896e-34 [J s = m^2 kg s^-1] (2007 CODATA)

member.name: F:MathNet.Numerics.SiConstants.DiracsConstant
member.summary: Reduced Planck's constant: h_bar = h / (2*Pi) [J s = m^2 kg s^-1] (2007 CODATA)

member.name: F:MathNet.Numerics.SiConstants.PlancksMass
member.summary: Planck mass: m_p = (h_bar*c_0/G)^(1/2) [kg] (2007 CODATA)

member.name: F:MathNet.Numerics.SiConstants.PlancksTemperature
member.summary: Planck temperature: T_p = (h_bar*c_0^5/G)^(1/2)/k [K] (2007 CODATA)

member.name: F:MathNet.Numerics.SiConstants.PlancksLength
member.summary: Planck length: l_p = h_bar/(m_p*c_0) [m] (2007 CODATA)

member.name: F:MathNet.Numerics.SiConstants.PlancksTime
member.summary: Planck time: t_p = l_p/c_0 [s] (2007 CODATA)

member.name: F:MathNet.Numerics.SiConstants.ElementaryCharge

member.name: F:MathNet.Numerics.SiConstants.MagneticFluxQuantum

member.name: F:MathNet.Numerics.SiConstants.ConductanceQuantum

member.name: F:MathNet.Numerics.SiConstants.JosephsonConstant

member.name: F:MathNet.Numerics.SiConstants.VonKlitzingConstant

member.name: F:MathNet.Numerics.SiConstants.NuclearMagneton

member.name: F:MathNet.Numerics.SiConstants.FineStructureConstant

member.name: F:MathNet.Numerics.SiConstants.HartreeEnergy

member.name: F:MathNet.Numerics.SiConstants.QuantumOfCirculation

member.name: F:MathNet.Numerics.SiConstants.FermiCouplingConstant

member.name: F:MathNet.Numerics.SiConstants.WeakMixingAngle

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.SampleList
member.summary: SampleList is a sorted list in ascending order for discrete function samples x=f(t) or value pairs (t,x). Multiple values x for the same t are replaced with the mean.
member.remarks: This list is designed for rare additions and removals only and is slow when adding items in not-ascending order. Better fill it directly in the constructor.

member.summary: Create a new sample list.

member.summary: Create a new sample list.

member.summary: Create a new sample list based on a copy of two arrays.
member.exception: If the dimensionality of the two arrays doesn't match.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.SampleList.EnsureCapacity(System.Int32)
member.summary: Doubles the capacity. Do not use this method directly, use instead.

member.summary: Append a sample to existing samples. Do not use this method directly, use instead.

member.summary: Insert a new sample. Do not use this method directly, use instead.

member.summary: Add a new sample to the list.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.SampleList.RemoveAt(System.Int32)
member.summary: Remove the sample at the given index.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.SampleList.Remove(System.Double)
member.summary: Remove all samples with a key exactly equal to t, where x=f(t) or (t,x).

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.SampleList.Clear
member.summary: Remove all samples from the list.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.SampleList.IndexOfT(System.Double)
member.summary: The index of the sample with a key exactly equal to t.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.SampleList.IndexOfX(System.Double)
member.summary: The index of the first sample with a value exactly equal to x.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.SampleList.SetX(System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Sets the X matching the given T (and sets its count to 1) or inserts a new sample. Do not use this to add a sample to the list!

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.SampleList.GetT(System.Int32)
member.summary: Get the key t stored at the given index, where x=f(t) or (t,x).

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.SampleList.GetX(System.Int32)
member.summary: Get the value x stored at the given index, where x=f(t) or (t,x).

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.SampleList.Locate(System.Double)
member.summary: Find the index i of a sample near t such that t[i] <= t <= t[i+1].
member.returns: The lower bound index of the interval, -1 or Size-1 if out of bounds.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.SampleList.Locate(System.Double,System.Int32)
member.summary: Find the index i of a sample near t such that t[i] <= t <= t[i+1].
member.remarks: This method is faster if the expected index is near nearIndex (compared to the list size) but may be slower otherwise (worst case: factor 2 slower, best case: log2(n) faster).
member.returns: The lower bound index of the interval, -1 or Size-1 if out of bounds.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.SampleList.LocateBisection(System.Double,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Bisection Search Helper. Do not use this method directly, use instead.

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.SingularValueDecomposition
member.summary: Singular Value Decomposition.

remarks.p: For an m-by-n matrix A with m >= n, the singular value decomposition is an m-by-n orthogonal matrix U, an n-by-n diagonal matrix S, and an n-by-n orthogonal matrix V so that A = U*S*V'.
The singular values, sigma[k] = S[k, k], are ordered so that sigma[0] >= sigma[1] >= ... >= sigma[n-1].
The singular value decomposition always exists, so the constructor will never fail. The matrix condition number and the effective numerical rank can be computed from this decomposition.

member.name: F:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.SingularValueDecomposition._singular
member.summary: Array for internal storage of singular values.

member.summary: Column dimensions.

member.name: F:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.SingularValueDecomposition.transpose
member.summary: Indicates whether all the results provided by the method or properties should be transposed.
member.remarks: (vermorel) The initial implementation was assuming that m >= n, but in fact, it is easy to handle the case m < n by transposing all the results.

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.Interpolation.Algorithms.PolynomialInterpolation
member.summary: Lagrange Polynomial Interpolation using Neville's Algorithm.

remarks.para: This algorithm supports differentiation, but doesn't support integration.
Consider to use the or at least one of the specially spaced barycentric alternatives like the or instead.

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.Distributions.StandardDistribution
member.summary: Pseudo-random generation of standard distributed deviates.

remarks.para:
For details about this distribution, see
Wikipedia - Normal distribution.
This implementation is based on the Box-Muller algorithm for generating random deviates with a normal distribution.

For details of the algorithm, see
Numerical recipes in C (chapter 7)

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.RandomSources.AdditiveLaggedFibonacciRandomSource
member.summary: Represents a Additive Lagged Fibonacci pseudo-random number generator.
member.remarks: The type bases upon the implementation in the Boost Random Number Library. It uses the modulus 232 and by default the "lags" 418 and 1279, which can be adjusted through the associated and properties. Some popular pairs are presented on Wikipedia - Lagged Fibonacci generator.

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.Distributions.NormalDistribution
member.summary: Pseudo-random generation of normal distributed deviates.

remarks.para:
For details about this distribution, see
Wikipedia - Normal distribution.
This implementation is based on the Box-Muller algorithm for generating random deviates with a normal distribution.

For details of the algorithm, see
Numerical recipes in C (chapter 7)
pdf: f(x) = 1/(s*sqrt(2*Pi))*exp(-(x-m)^2/(2*s^2)); m = mu (location), s = sigma (scale)

summary.para: The ComplexFourierTransformation provides algorithms for one, two and three dimensional fast fourier transformations (FFT) on complex vectors.
This class caches precomputations locally, thus consider reusing/caching it.

member.summary: Construct a complex fourier transformation instance.

member.summary: Construct a complex fourier transformation instance with a given convention.

member.summary: Generate the expected sample points in time space.
member.param: The sampling rate of the time-space data.
The real & complex numbers count together as only one sample.

member.summary: Generate the expected sample points in frequency space.
member.param: The sampling rate of the time-space data.
The real & complex numbers count together as only one sample.

member.summary: Inplace Forward Transformation in one dimension. Size must be Power of Two.
member.param: Complex samples (even = real, odd = imaginary). Length must be a power of two.

member.summary: Inplace Forward Transformation in one dimension. Size must be Power of Two.
member.param: Complex samples. Length must be a power of two.
member.remarks: This method provides a simple shortcut if your data is already available as type instances. However, if not, consider using the overloaded method with double pairs instead, it requires less internal copying.

member.summary: Evaluates the minimum distance to the next distinguishable number near the argument value.
member.returns: Relative Epsilon (positive double or NaN).
member.remarks: Evaluates the negative epsilon. The more common positive epsilon is equal to two times this negative epsilon.

member.summary: Evaluates the minimum distance to the next distinguishable number near the argument value.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Number.Increment(System.Double)
member.summary: Increments a floating point number to the next bigger number representable by the data type.
member.remarks: The incrementation step length depends on the provided value. Increment(double.MaxValue) will return positive infinity.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Number.Decrement(System.Double)
member.summary: Decrements a floating point number to the next smaller number representable by the data type.
member.remarks: The decrementation step length depends on the provided value. Decrement(double.MinValue) will return negative infinity.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Number.NumbersBetween(System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Evaluates the count of numbers between two double numbers
member.remarks: The second number is included in the number, thus two equal numbers evaluate to zero and two neighbour numbers evaluate to one. Therefore, what is returned is actually the count of numbers between plus 1.

summary.para: The RealFourierTransformation provides algorithms for one, two and three dimensional fast fourier transformations (FFT) on real vectors.
This class caches precomputations locally, thus consider reusing/caching it.

Output samples for te second vector.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Fn.Sinc(System.Double)
member.summary: Normalized Sinc (sinus cardinalis) Function.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Fn.FactorialLn(System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns the natural logarithm of the factorial (n!) for an integer value > 0.
member.returns: A value ln(value!) for value > 0

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Fn.Factorial(System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns the factorial (n!) of an integer number > 0. Consider using instead.
member.returns: A value value! for value > 0
member.remarks: If you need to multiply or divide various such factorials, consider using the logarithmic version instead so you can add instead of multiply and subtract instead of divide, and then exponentiate the result using . This will also completely circumvent the problem that factorials easily become very large.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Fn.BinomialCoefficient(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns the binomial coefficient of n and k as a double precision number.
member.remarks: If you need to multiply or divide various such coefficients, consider using the logarithmic version instead so you can add instead of multiply and subtract instead of divide, and then exponentiate the result using .

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Fn.BinomialCoefficientLn(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns the natural logarithm of the binomial coefficient of n and k as a double precision number.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Fn.GammaLn(System.Double)
member.summary: Returns the natural logarithm of Gamma for a real value > 0.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Fn.Gamma(System.Double)
member.summary: Returns the gamma function for real values (except at 0, -1, -2, ...). For numeric stability, consider to use GammaLn for positive values.
member.returns: A value Gamma(value) for value != 0,-1,-2,...

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Fn.IncompleteGammaRegularized(System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Obsolete. Please use GammaRegularized instead, with the same parameters (method was renamed).

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Fn.GammaRegularized(System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Returns the regularized lower incomplete gamma function P(a,x) = 1/Gamma(a) * int(exp(-t)t^(a-1),t=0..x) for real a > 0, x > 0.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Fn.Digamma(System.Double)
member.summary: Returns the digamma (psi) function of real values (except at 0, -1, -2, ...). Digamma is the logarithmic derivative of the function.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Fn.Beta(System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Returns the Euler Beta function of real valued z > 0, w > 0. Beta(z,w) = Beta(w,z).

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Fn.BetaLn(System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Returns the natural logarithm of the Euler Beta function of real valued z > 0, w > 0. BetaLn(z,w) = BetaLn(w,z).

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Fn.IncompleteBetaRegularized(System.Double,System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Obsolete. Please use BetaRegularized instead, with the same parameters (method was renamed).

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Fn.BetaRegularized(System.Double,System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Returns the regularized lower incomplete beta function I_x(a,b) = 1/Beta(a,b) * int(t^(a-1)*(1-t)^(b-1),t=0..x) for real a > 0, b > 0, 1 >= x >= 0.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Fn.Erf(System.Double)
member.summary: Returns the error function erf(x) = 2/sqrt(pi) * int(exp(-t^2),t=0..x)

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Fn.ErfInverse(System.Double)
member.summary: Returns the inverse error function erf^-1(x).

remarks.p: The algorithm uses a minimax approximation by rational functions and the result has a relative error whose absolute value is less than 1.15e-9.
See the page for more details.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Fn.HarmonicNumber(System.Int32)
member.summary: Evaluates the n-th harmonic number Hn = sum(1/k,k=1..n).
member.remarks: See Wikipedia - Harmonic Number

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.QRDecomposition
member.summary: QR Decomposition.
member.remarks:
For an m-by-n matrix A with m >= n, the QR decomposition is an m-by-n orthogonal matrix Q and an n-by-n upper triangular matrix R so that A = Q*R.
The QR decomposition always exists, even if the matrix does not have full rank, so the constructor will never fail. The primary use of the QR decomposition is in the least squares solution of non-square systems of simultaneous linear equations. This will fail if IsFullRank() returns false.

member.returns: X that minimizes the two norm of Q*R*X-B.

The sample point values x(t). Supports both lists and arrays.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Interpolation.Interpolation.CreateOnChebyshevFirstKindPoints(System.Double,System.Double,System.Collections.Generic.IList{System.Double})
member.summary: Create a polynomial interpolation based on chebyshev (first kind) points, that is, "t(i) = 0.5*(b+a) + 0.5*(b-a)*cos(Pi*(2*i+1)/(2*n))".
member.param: The left (smallest) sample point t bound.
The right (biggest) sample point t bound.
The sample point values x(t). Supports both lists and arrays.
member.returns: An interpolation scheme optimized for the given sample points and values, which can then be used to compute interpolations and extrapolations on arbitrary points.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Interpolation.Interpolation.GenerateChebyshevFirstKindSamplePoints(System.Double,System.Double,System.Int32)
member.summary: Generate a set of chebyshev points of the first kind in the interval [a,b]. These are the expected points t for the values v(t) to be provided in .
member.param: Number of sample nodes to generate.
member.returns: Chebyshev points (first kind) in the interval [a,b], i.e. 0.5*(b+a) + 0.5*(b-a)*cos(Pi*(2*i+1)/(2*n))

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Interpolation.Interpolation.CreateOnChebyshevSecondKindPoints(System.Double,System.Double,System.Collections.Generic.IList{System.Double})
member.summary: Create a polynomial interpolation based on chebyshev (second kind) points, that is, "t(i) = 0.5*(b+a) + 0.5*(b-a)*cos(Pi*i/n)".
member.param: The left (smallest) sample point t bound.
The right (biggest) sample point t bound.
The sample point values x(t). Supports both lists and arrays.
member.returns: An interpolation scheme optimized for the given sample points and values, which can then be used to compute interpolations and extrapolations on arbitrary points.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Interpolation.Interpolation.GenerateChebyshevSecondKindSamplePoints(System.Double,System.Double,System.Int32)
member.summary: Generate a set of chebyshev points of the second kind in the interval [a,b]. These are the expected points t for the values v(t) to be provided in .
member.param: Number of sample nodes to generate.
member.returns: Chebyshev points (second kind) in the interval [a,b], i.e. 0.5*(b+a) + 0.5*(b-a)*cos(Pi*i/n)

member.name: F:MathNet.Numerics.RandomSources.MersenneTwisterRandomSource.LowerMask
member.summary: Represents the least significant r bits. This field is constant.
member.remarks: The value of this constant is 0x7fffffff.

member.name: F:MathNet.Numerics.RandomSources.MersenneTwisterRandomSource.UIntToDoubleMultiplier

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.Statistics.Accumulator
member.summary: The Accumulator provides online algorithms to computes the first statistical moments and their derivatives.

remarks.p: The Accumulator provides memory efficient online algorithms to compute the first statistical moments (mean, variance) and their derivatives (sigma, error estimate).
The Accumulator is not thread safe.

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.RandomSources.XorShiftRandomSource
member.summary: Represents a xorshift pseudo-random number generator with period 2^128-1.
member.remarks: The type bases upon the implementation presented in the CP article "A fast equivalent for System.Random" and the theoretical background on xorshift random number generators published by George Marsaglia in this paper "Xorshift RNGs".

member.remarks: To normalize a quaternion to a length of 1, use the method. All unit quaternions form a 3-sphere.

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.LUDecomposition
member.summary: LU Decomposition.
member.remarks: For an m-by-n matrix A with m >= n, the LU decomposition is an m-by-n unit lower triangular matrix L, an n-by-n upper triangular matrix U, and a permutation vector pivot of length m so that A(piv,:) = L*U. If m < n, then L is m-by-m and U is m-by-n. The LU decomposition with pivoting always exists, even if the matrix is singular, so the constructor will never fail. The primary use of the LU decomposition is in the solution of square systems of simultaneous linear equations. This will fail if IsNonSingular() returns false.

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.EigenvalueDecomposition
member.summary: Eigenvalues and eigenvectors of a real matrix.
member.remarks: If A is symmetric, then A = V*D*V' where the eigenvalue matrix D is diagonal and the eigenvector matrix V is orthogonal. I.e. A = V.Multiply(D.Multiply(V.Transpose())) and V.Multiply(V.Transpose()) equals the identity matrix. If A is not symmetric, then the eigenvalue matrix D is block diagonal with the real eigenvalues in 1-by-1 blocks and any complex eigenvalues, lambda + i*mu, in 2-by-2 blocks, [lambda, mu; -mu, lambda]. The columns of V represent the eigenvectors in the sense that A*V = V*D, i.e. A.Multiply(V) equals V.Multiply(D). The matrix V may be badly conditioned, or even singular, so the validity of the equation A = V*D*Inverse(V) depends upon V.cond().

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.Distributions.ZipfDistribution
member.summary: Pseudo-random generator of Zipf distributed deviates.

remarks.p: The density of the continuous Zipf distribution is defined on [1, +infinity), the density is proportional to x^s where s > 1 is the skew.
See the Wikipedia for more information about Zipf distribution.
